data.title: atom editor get closed when i drag and drop the image from firefox browser
data.body:
I'm using Atom 1.0 stable on Ubuntu 14.04 here is my system info: 
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 14.04.2 LTS
Release:    14.04
Codename:   trusty
Accidentally , Once I drag and drop the image in atom editor from firefox browser.. after drop the image the atom editor get closed automaticaally.. i didn't notice whether my files are lost or not.. 

you can reproduce the same by drag and drop the image from firefox browser into atom editor.

data.title: Markdown preview slows down on larger files
data.body: The Markdown preview slows down the editor with more than 5,000 chars.

data.title: Issue with multiple cursor history and atom-alignment plugin
data.body:
This is being triggered by a plugin, but I believe it belongs here because plugins _probably_ shouldn't be responsible for micro-managing things like history.

The package `atom-alignment` just aligns cursors.  Unfortunately it adds one history event per cursor, which is quite annoying.

``` json
{
  "a"|: 1,
  "ab"|: 1,
  "abc"|: 1
```

align cursors

``` json
{
  "a"  |: 1,
  "ab" |: 1,
  "abc"|: 1
```

undo (note nothing happens, it's resetting the 3rd cursor which didn't move):

``` json
{
  "a"  |: 1,
  "ab" |: 1,
  "abc"|: 1
```

undo:

``` json
{
  "a"  |: 1,
  "ab"|: 1,
  "abc"|: 1
```

undo:

``` json
{
  "a"|: 1,
  "ab"|: 1,
  "abc"|: 1
```

data.title: Find in Project searches performs search in recently removed project folders
data.body:
I'm having a reproducible issue in Atom 1.0.2 Mac where when I run Find in Project the search also searches in projects that I've removed from the sidebar and as well as the currently selected / open project.

The only way I've managed to get around it is by quitting and reopening Atom.

data.title: Add real path negation to workspace::scan
data.body:
Closes https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace/issues/149

See atom/scandal#29

data.title: TextEditor::pasteText does not emit did-insert-text
data.body: `insertText` calls `@emitWillInsertTextEvent(text)` and later `@emitter.emit 'did-insert-text', didInsertEvent`, but `pasteText` only does the former and never the latter.

data.title: Unable to select text by highlighting with mouse
data.body:
Atom 1.0.2 on Ubuntu 14.04.02 in 
Virtualbox 4.3.20  with 3d acceleration enabled on Win 8.1 Pro physical host
Mouse integration is enabled - when disabled, highlighting of text works, however mouse cursor disappears.

Seems related: https://discuss.atom.io/t/mouse-selection-problem/16623
Chromium version issue?

data.title: Shrink or scroll editor when panels at bottom open up
data.body:
If this has been raised before or if this is the wrong repo, please correct me. I couldn't find a previous issue for it. I've raised this issue at the atom linter repository originally, see https://github.com/atom-community/linter/issues/758, but we felt this was a more widespread issue and not the responsibility of the linter package.

Considering that [linter might get integrated into the atom core](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7353), it's probably a good idea to handle this issue in atom core anyway.

The problem is with panels that open up at the bottom of the Atom window (e.g. find & replace, linter) while you are working on code which is at the bottom of a file. These panels overlap your code when they open, hiding the code from view and forcing you to scroll up.

Type something erroneous at the bottom:
![ss](https://www.dropbox.com/s/aplhj66dn0mohfv/Screenshot%202015-07-21%2011.57.04.png?dl=1)

Panel shows up and overlaps your code:
![ss](https://www.dropbox.com/s/qqren1bvolmc2l9/Screenshot%202015-07-21%2011.57.35.png?dl=1)

The problem is particularly troublesome with automatically opened windows, like linter. The find & replace panel never bothered me like that, because it's triggered manually with a keyboard command, so you're not focussed on typing code anyway. But with the linter panel, you are, and it's very disturbing to have the panel suddenly show up and block your view of your code.

A proposed work around has been to enable the setting "Scroll Past End", but while this alleviates the issue a little bit, it doesn't solve it and it can still happen when you forgot to scroll further up.

A better solution would probably be for the panels to not overlap the editor window, but rather push it up causing it to shrink. I realize this might cause the opposite problem though, e.g. if you're typing at the top of the file, then that code would be pushed out of view.

Any idea's?

data.title: ES6 syntax hi-light for const destructuring assignment not showing
text editor freezes up opening contents of http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/less.js/2.5.1/less.min.js
data.body: works great in sublime

data.title: Manual keymaps sometimes being ignored in preference of package defaults
data.body:
I'm an vim-mode user and my keyboard layout is ABNT-2. This means that, when using Atom, I need to remap the "?" keymap to `ex-mode` command, otherwise my keymaps are wrong.

Sometimes, specialy when I upgrade `vim-mode` package, their keymaps are overriding mine. Here's a screenshot:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/138037/8879530/43a46ff0-3208-11e5-9144-47ce2a221330.png)

As you can see, vim-mode is capturing my keymap, and the manual keymaps defined in Atom are being ignored. This is a recurring issue - most of the time, I don't know if my keymaps are being overriden or not.

data.title: Modifying file in atom causin excessive git diff
data.body: I'm seeing when modifying a file on a single line it causes git to show a change on every line in the file making the commit log unreadable.

data.title: Update docs for Marker::onDidChange callback
Update language-javascript, python, and go
data.body:
- Javascript 0.82.0 now tokenizes the `$` in  `$something` as an instance constructor and also fixes tokenization when destructuring in `const` assignments (`const [first, second, ...rest] = array);`)
- Python 0.38.0 correctly tokenizes `self.something` now
- Go 0.31.0 adds the `fmt printf` snippet for debugging

data.title: Can't access global commands from Atom
data.body:
Mac OS X 10.10.3
Atom 1.0

Hello, I'm the creator of [autocomplete-elixir](https://github.com/iraasta/autocomplete-elixir) and I've got a problem with BufferedProcess spawning in atom on OS X systems.

Whenever I try to spawn global 'elixir' command from atom's BufferedProcess (childprocess.spawn doesn't work either) when it's open on OS X using Finder it cannot find it. Using the absolute path launches `elixir` successfully, but then `elixir` fails on it's dependencies in PATH variable.
There is no problem when launching atom from commandline what so ever.
It works fine on any other OS too.

iraasta/autocomplete-elixir#14

data.body:
Recently, I'm seeing a lot of these broken avatar images for packages:

![ss](https://www.dropbox.com/s/m35tfpv7cyv9o6g/Screenshot%202015-07-24%2020.55.39.png?dl=1)

They are supposedly coming from the cache, but for some reason don't show up:

data.title: Remember toggle soft wrap option
data.body: I would be great if the value of this option is saved somehow. How one has to turn it on every time. Maybe it should be saved separately for different file formats, maybe globally.

data.title: Jade language support
data.body: Please add Jade language support in the base code? It'd be really handy. Thanks!

data.title: Search performance
data.body: I have a 636k XML/XSD file that I have to use for reference frequently in a project. If I open this file to search for a tag, like "E04", atom locks up and blocks for about 6 seconds looking for "E", which there are 30,000 of. If I type quickly enough, and get "E0" typed quickly, then atom doesn't find many, and doesn't lock up. It seems that the block is while atom tries to decorate all the E's it found with a little box. The search itself doesn't seem to be the issue, as evidenced by the lack of freezing when I quickly type an uncommon search string. atom is version 1.0.2-9432598, built from source, on 64 bit Arch linux

data.title: Save Warning on Tab Move
data.body: When moving an unsaved file from one window to another (by dragging the tab from window to window), Atom displays a save warning, despite the file not being closed.

data.title: Fire event before a pane is destroyed.
data.body:
Rationale: I don't like losing my tabs when I close a pane (or accidentally close the wrong pane), so want to be able to move them into another pane just before the pane is destroyed.

This adds both `pane.onWillDestroy -> ...` and `workspace.onWillDestoryPane (pane) -> ...`, analogous to the pane item callbacks.

data.title: Enable Dictionary lookup in OS X
data.body: On OS X, the standard Dictionary service does not work (usually set to ctrl + option + D or three-finger-tap). While there is a package that provides a workaround (https://atom.io/packages/dictionary), this should not be necessary, and the system-provided version of this is much less intrusive.

data.title: Upgrade service hub again
data.body: The new service-hub (0.6.2) has fewer changes than when I first tried to upgrade (0.6.0).

data.title: Crash on Network Share going down
data.body: On my windows machine I edited a file on a samba share on a Linux machine. When the share went down, Atom crashed, leaving me unable to rescue any made changes since last save

data.title: Fix indentation for languages without indent pattern
data.body: Fixes #8013

data.title: "Find" doesn't move the cursor to the match
data.body: Not sure if a bug or a feature, but "find"ing stuff doesn't move the cursor to the first match (which I'd say is the expected behavior as all other editors I know do it and because it doesn't make any sense not to move the cursor to the first match as the whole point of searching something is to see it/where it is).

data.title: [Performance] Converting a 2k lines JSON file from spaces to tabs takes ~15sec
data.body:
Converting a ~2k lines (2386) JSON file from spaces to tabs takes around 15 seconds (with the UI completely freezed).

The JSON doesn't have any errors and it has been formatted by an external tool, so this is just a "replace each 4 spaces with 1 tab" operation.
